Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Innovative Low Cost Agricultural Soil Sensing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to create a new low cost decision support tool to help growers optimize resources and grow more crop per drop. The company is developing extremely low cost environmental sensors that will enable growers to capture highly granular environmental data in the field and derive optimal irrigation strategies through the application of data science. Water is a major contributor to crop yields and growers struggle to deal will water scarcity and quality, coupled with variability in the soils and irrigation systems. Through the use of a data driven, closed loop decision support tool, growers will be better equipped to deal with variability, make better resource use decisions and improve crop yields. This new approach has the potential to enable growers to increase yields by as much as 15% while maintaining or reducing water use.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will enable the detection of moisture and soil texture in soils using a low cost soil moisture sensor based on magnetics. Growers rely on field data, including soil moisture, to make daily decisions that impact plant health. The most significant decision is when to apply water and in what quantity. Current approaches to detecting soil moisture (and other soil characteristics) in an automated fashion are expensive and unreliable leaving growers searching for alternatives. The objective of this project is to develop a sensitive, accurate, and reliable sensor that measures soil moisture using a novel, magnetics based approach. During the project the team will build prototype sensors, test them in lab and field environments, develop algorithms for calibrating the sensor, and explore new approaches to presenting multidimensional field data to growers in a manner that facilitates understanding and decision making.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Project Outcomes

In order to create a viable wireless soil moisture sensor, we needed to take on a number of goals to move from idea to viable product. In addiiton, our NSF meeting in September reiterated the need to use US Taxpayer funds well, and deliver the goods. We were determined to build a company with NSF help.

Goal # 1: Magnetic soil sensing element to detect soil moisture levels.

We built a number of test sensors and evolved the design using rapid 3D printing techniques for our sensor over 20 times, with incremental changes.  With this approach, we were able to get to a point of clear low-cost goals.

We confirmed additional attributes sensing capability of the coils, with a series of tests with custom firmware. We were able to show variation in responses, though works remains to be done. We are planning to work on this at a much deeper level in Phase 2, if funded.

We looked at other signal aspects and found very clear linearity that we believe holds the most promise for the next step in research, which expect to address in Phase 2. 

Goal #2 , part 1: Develop an ultra-low-energy radio “head unit”. 

We were determined to eliminate batteries in the longer term – this is both more economical and better for the environment. This is also a breakthrough and hard to accomplish as customers want to see updates every 15 minutes. Battery-free systems are now in test - a major accomplishment for us in low energy systems. 

We noticed that growers were intrigued by our radio systems capability. With this insight, we seized the opportunity, and converted the radio head unit into a commercial product, that also enabled additional products. Due to our focus on energy efficiency, we were able to create a highly differentiated product.

At this time, we have completed trials with multiple customers. All the trials have been positive, and we are now moving to scale out our product line and our production process.

Goal #2, part 2: Network systems

We ramped up very fast in this area with extensive development work.  We now run a Network Operations Center to ensure our systems in the field are being constantly monitored, and we are aware of any issues before any one else, allowing us to pro-actively support our clients. This has become a differentiator for us.

Goal #3: Develop a web-based application

We got strong feedback from users as part of our Lean Development process that they wanted more than “just more fancy charts”. They wanted actionable information. We have built the foundation for this. Customers are using an alpha version of the software right now.

Goal #4 : Move forward on commercialization

NSF-provided training on Lean Development at Washington, and repeatedly emphasized the importance of using the tax-payer funded grants to develop strong companies in the US. We believe we have made major progress on this.

We knew that funds from the NSF alone would never be enough, and knew that needed a significant boost, so we could also hire in a full-time team. With operations in Silicon Valley, our expenses are above average. Raising funds was critical.  

We successfully raised additional funds.

At the time of the NSF Kickoff meeting in DC, we had raised a total of $1.6M. We used Lean Development to improve our business plan further. 

We were able to raise an additional $1.805M in funding to keep growing.

We built a company

We recruited new talent to create a tight team with values, processes and products - and with the technical and business foundation to continue. 

Staffing

We hired on 7 more full time staff after NSF funding, which included recruiting the Senseterra team of Alan Broad and Robert Coates who have published numerous papers along with Michael Delwiche at UC Davis, on sensing, irrigation and more. We were also able to hire in Andrew Wright who used to run global R&D for Cypress Semiconductor, as our professional CEO. 

Overall, the outcome of the NSF funding has been to enable us to create a technology company, based in the US, with employment in the US, manufacturing in the US and customers in the US and abroad, at the cutting edge of AgTech.

We are very grateful to the NSF for supporting us, and hope that we will be able to leverage Phase 2 support to continue building our company, right here in San Jose, CA, for the benefit of growers across the US first, and later the world.
